speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Tesla's third quarter twenty twenty two q and a webcast. My name is Martin Vieka, VP of Investor Relations, and I'm joined today by Elon Musk, Zachary Kirkhorn, and a number of other executives. Our Q3 results were announced at about three pm Central Time in the update that we published at the same link as this webcast. During the call, we will discuss our business outlook and make forward looking statements. These comments are based on our predictions and expectations as of today.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Actual events or results could differ materially due to a number of risks and uncertainties, including those mentioned in our most recent filings with the SEC. During the Q and A session portion of today's call, please limit yourself to one question and one follow-up. Please use the raise hand button to join the question queue. But before we jump into Q and A, Elon has some opening remarks. Elon?

speaker: Elon Musk
text: Thank you, Martin. So just to do a Q3 recap. Q3 was another record quarter on finding levels. We had our industry leading operating margin reach seventeen percent and our free cash flow surpassed three billion in Q3 and approached nine billion dollars in the past twelve months. As our factories ramp, we're looking forward to a record breaking q q four.

speaker: Elon Musk
text: So it's it really, you know, knock knock on wood, it looks looks like we'll have an an epic end of end of year. So q four is looking extremely good. On the production ramp, Giga Berlin achieved another milestone of two thousand cars made in a week with very good quality and is is ramping rapidly. Giga Austin or Giga Texas should reach this milestone very soon. And and in fact, just yesterday, we if you extrapolate yesterday's old rate, it would be two thousand.

speaker: Elon Musk
text: Our production of four thousand six and eighty cells has tripled in Q3 compared to the previous quarter. We are finally gaining rapid traction on the four thousand six hundred eighty cell and its output is growing rapidly and we expect it to start incorporating in cars and having it be a significant portion of our production here in Texas in the coming months. We also have our second generation of manufacturing equipment for four thousand six hundred eighty cells in Texas, which continues to show great progress along with our original pilot line Fremont. The Fremont factory team once again reached record production in Q3 and we intend to keep raising production in Fremont. Regarding Autopilot, at the end of September, we hosted our second AI day, entered the first prototype of our Oculus robot, the latest updates on our Dojo training computer and wide range of improvements of full self driving software.

speaker: Elon Musk
text: Our vehicles have now driven nearly sixty miles in full self driving beta mode and the server continues to grow exponentially. Our goal with that AI day was to push recruiting and we've seen a massive influx of world class artificial intelligence engineer and scientist resume. So it generated a tremendous amount of interest from some of the best AI researchers in the world. I can't emphasize the importance of this enough because I think finally, it has become clear to the smallest AI technologists in the world that Tesla is among the very best. So, and this this quarter, we expect to go to wide release of full self driving beta in North America.

speaker: Elon Musk
text: So anyone who has ordered a full self driving beta, full self driving will have access to the FSD beta program this year, probably about a month from now. So and then, obviously, a new car new anyone who buys a car and and purchase purchase a full self driving option will immediately have that available to them. So the safety that we're seeing when the car is in FSD mode is actually significantly greater than the safety we're seeing than what when it is not, which is a key threshold for going to a wide beta. Let's see with respect to demand. We've got a lot of questions about demand in recent weeks.

speaker: Elon Musk
text: I can't emphasize enough. We have excellent demand for Q4 and we expect to sell every car that we make for as far into the future as we can see. So the factories are running at full speed and we're delivering every car we make and keeping operating margins strong. We're still a very small percentage of of the total vehicles on the road. Other two billion cars and trucks on the road, we only have about three and a half million.

speaker: Elon Musk
text: So we've got a long way to go to even reach one percent of the global fleet. Let's see. Based on what people are based on on many things, but certainly questions I get on Twitter about buybacks. I I think every one of our board members has gotten questions about buybacks. We've debated the buyback idea extensively at what level.

speaker: Elon Musk
text: The board generally thinks that it makes sense to do a buyback, but we want to work through the right process to do a buyback. But it is certainly possible for us to do a buyback on the order of five billion dollars ten billion dollars even in the downside scenario of next year, even if next year is a very difficult year, we still have the ability to do a five to ten billion dollars buyback. This is obviously pending board review and approval. So it's it's likely that we'll do some some meaningful buyback. So in conclusion, while the market themes revolve around the short term, it's very important to focus on the long term.

speaker: Elon Musk
text: I can't emphasize this enough with investors and I think long long time investors obviously recognize this with Tesla. We have your sort of local ups and downs, but long term trend has been extremely good. And several years ago, I said, I think on an earnings on an earnings call that I that I I thought it was possible for Tesla to be worth more than Apple, which was then the highest cap company, I think, in the market. And Apple's time, I think, was around seven hundred billion dollars. I said it required incredible executions, at least some luck, And we didn't even indeed achieve that.

speaker: Elon Musk
text: Tesla went back to our past. The Apple's market kept the time. And and now I'm of the opinion that we can far exceed Apple's current market cap. In fact, I I see a potential path for Tesla to be worth more than Apple and Saudi Aramco combined. So now that doesn't mean it will happen or that will be easy.

speaker: Elon Musk
text: In fact, I think it will it will be very difficult to require a lot of work, some very creative new products, tremendous expansion, and always good luck. For the first time, I am seeing I see a way for Tesla to be, let's say, roughly twice the value of Saudi Aramco. I think that's I I haven't haven't quite seen that yet. I mean, I haven't this is the first time I've seen seen that potential. So I mean, we have an incredible product portfolio.

speaker: Elon Musk
text: I think we've got the most exciting product portfolio of any company on earth. Some of which you've heard about, some of which you haven't. We're in the the the final lap for Cybertruck. We're both building the Cybertruck line here at Giga Texas Austin. And make a lot of progress in the robotaxi platform design.

speaker: Elon Musk
text: And oh, and then with, yeah, with respect to batteries, we're moving as fast as possible to have to to achieve a thousand gigawatt hours a year of production capacity in the United States vertically integrated. So anode cathode, lithium refining, removing a a tough speed to to do that. So think it's an incredibly exciting future and really an unprecedented future. But none of this would be possible without the incredible team that we have here at Tesla. So I'd like to give a huge shout out to all of our factory employees, engineers, executives, the whole Tesla team.

speaker: Elon Musk
text: You guys rock. You're the ones making it happen. Thank you.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Thank very much. And Zach has some opening remarks as well. Yeah, thanks Martin. Just to continue on Elon's theme, I just want to thank and congratulate the Tesla team for achieving record vehicle deliveries, production, and storage deployments in the third quarter. On automotive profitability, our GAAP operating margin was seventeen point two percent, with automotive gross margin at twenty seven point nine percent.

speaker: Zachary Kirkhorn
text: Operating margin is one of our best yet, with improvements in operating leverage. However, Austin and Berlin ramp costs weighed on our margins, particularly if you compare it to Q1. Removing regulatory credits and Austin and Berlin, our operating margins would have been our strongest yet, and auto gross margin would have been nearly thirty percent. Note that while small and growing, each car we build in Austin and Berlin is contributing positively to profitability. We also continue to experience margin headwinds associated with macroeconomic conditions, as we've discussed at length on prior calls.

speaker: Zachary Kirkhorn
text: In particular, raw materials, logistics, and foreign exchange was a big part of this past quarter. On energy profitability, we achieved our strongest gross profit yet for this business, driven primarily by record volumes of our Megapack and Firewall products. Our free cash flows were also a record, despite an increase in cars in transit at the end of the quarter, which has a negative impact on working capital. Specifically on cars in transit, as noted in our press release on October second, we have started to experience limits on outbound logistics capacity, which we didn't anticipate. This issue is particularly present for ships from Shanghai to Europe, and local trucking within certain parts of the US and Europe.

speaker: Zachary Kirkhorn
text: Our historical operating pattern of batch building by delivery region leads to extreme concentrations of outbound needs in the final weeks of each quarter. Just to put this in perspective, roughly two thirds of our Q3 deliveries occurred in September, and one third in the final two weeks. As a result, we have begun to smooth regional builds throughout the quarter to reduce our peak needs for outbound logistics. We expect this to simplify our operations, reduce costs, and improve the experience of our customers. As we look ahead, our plans show that we're on track for the fifty percent annual growth in production this year, although we are tracking supply chain risks which are beyond our control.

speaker: Zachary Kirkhorn
text: On the delivery side, we do expect to be just under fifty percent growth due to an increase in the cars in transit at the end of the year, as noted just above. This means that, again, you should expect a gap between production and deliveries in q four, and those cars in transit will be delivered shortly to their customers upon arrival to their destination in q one. Austin and Berlin ramp costs will continue to weigh on margins, although we expect the impact to be less than what we saw in Q3. And as Elon mentioned, we are continuing to build as many cars as possible while also maintaining strong operating margins. Thank you.

speaker: Martin Viecha
text: Thank you very much. And let's go first through the shareholder questions. The first shareholder question is, given the stringent battery content and assembly requirements for consumer tax credit eligibility under the inflation reduction act, Can you speak to Tesla's ability to meet those thresholds in each of twenty twenty three, twenty twenty four and twenty twenty five with your existing and planned supply chain?

text: Well, yeah, I mean, I think just at a high level, I'd say we do expect to fully meet the IRA's requirements. Do you want to add?

Expect Treasury to publish detailed guidance by the end of the year. Until such time, it's difficult to fully determine the eligibility criteria, but we believe Tesla is very well positioned to capture a significant share of that for solar storage and also electric vehicles.

So in fact, we were just fundamentally running out of of there weren't enough boats, there weren't enough trains, there weren't enough car carriers to actually support the wave because they got too big. So whether whether we like it or not, we actually have to smooth out the delivery of cars intra quarter because there are just odd enough transportation objects to move them around.
